text: this is kit Eaton for the New York Times
whether or not you're writing the next
oscar-winning film or are merely an
amateur screenplay writer perhaps like
fade in mobile may be perfect if
inspiration strikes for the next bit of
your film while you're on the move and
you have to write down your idea before
you get back to your main computer fade
in mobile which is free for both iOS and
Android is a great screenplay writing
app it's extremely unfussy basically
just being an interface that lets you
type in text and display it on your
tablet or phone in the right format with
character names and scene titles and so
on I like this type of writing
environment because there are a few
distractions for when you're trying to
get an idea out of your mind and onto
the page the app lets you import script
files that you've written on other
devices but the free edition only lets
you work on one script at a time and is
limited with the type of files you can
import to enable you to work on more
scripts at once and to access more file
types you have to pay $5 for both iOS
and Android editions of the app on iOS a
great alternative is scripts Pro this is
another uncluttered and unfussy script
editing and writing app which has a few
neat touches I particularly like its
suggestions box which pops up when
you're typing something like a character
name or location so you don't have to
type it over and over again scripts Pro
also lets you edit files written on a
popular desktop script writing software
final draft but this level of usefulness
does come at a price the app costs $12
Android device owners have the option of
dub script which has a very neat editing
trick whereby you just type in in plain
text without fussing about tabbing or
indentation or anything and then the app
tries to auto format it for you by
detecting what you've written this is a
very effective tool and may make this
app suitable for beginner screenplay
writers plus it's free and that's it
from me oh just exit stage right
Oh
